Sorry, I forgot to mention that Yakiotoshi is not a flaw but a feature 
and=
 exists and the machi end of the sword, not the Kissaki end. That is 
somet=
hing completely different again.

Cheers

Richard

Richard Turner wrote:
>
=
> Hi Elliot, no offence, but do not try to confuse your sword with a Juyo
>=
 or higher sword unless yours is of the same level. The hamon running off
>=
 the kissaki IS a fatal flaw, make no bones about that. Swords with fatal
>=
 flaws that make Tokubetsu Hozon, Juyo or Yashu saku are swords of
> extrao=
rdinary worth, and a flaw that is fatal can not take away it's
> history. T=
hese swords are typically famous because they are rare, or
> were carried b=
y someone important or famous. General swords, made by the
> not so famous =
sword smiths, no matter how nice will most likely fail all
> attempts at ka=
nteisho if theirs is a fatal flaw like the hamon running
> off the Ha or Ki=
ssaki, a Hagiri and the likes.
>
> We all learn hard lessons and we never l=
ike being told that our hard
> earned and well spent money if for naught, b=
ut this is a mugs game, it
> takes nerves of steel and a firm resolve. All =
I can suggest is to get
> over it and move on. I mean that in the nicest po=
ssible way. I am not
> trying to be smart, just realistic.
>
> Good luck
>
=
> Richard Turner
